title: What AI can tell us about microscope slides
description: A friendly introduction to Foundation Models for Computational Pathology
author: Rachel Thomas

title: A New Chapter for fast.ai: How To Solve It With Code
description: fast.ai is joining Answer.AI, and we’re announcing a new kind of educational experience, ‘How To Solve It With Code’
author: Jeremy Howard

title: In defense of screen time
description: Pundits say my husband and I are parenting wrong.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: A new old kind of R&D lab
description: Answer.AI is a new kind of AI R&D lab which creates practical end-user products based on foundational research breakthroughs.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Can LLMs learn from a single example?
description: We’ve noticed an unusual training pattern in fine-tuning LLMs. At first we thought it’s a bug, but now we think it shows LLMs can learn effectively from a single example.
author: Jeremy Howard and Jonathan Whitaker

title: AI and Power: The Ethical Challenges of Automation, Centralization, and Scale
description: Moving AI ethics beyond explainability and fairness to empowerment and justice
author: Rachel Thomas

title: AI Safety and the Age of Dislightenment
description: Model licensing & surveillance will likely be counterproductive by concentrating power in unsustainable ways
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Is Avoiding Extinction from AI Really an Urgent Priority?
description: The history of technology suggests that the greatest risks come not from the tech, but from the people who control it
author: Seth Lazar, Jeremy Howard, & Arvind Narayanan

title: Mojo may be the biggest programming language advance in decades
description: Mojo is a new programming language, based on Python, which fixes Python’s performance and deployment problems.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: From Deep Learning Foundations to Stable Diffusion
description: We’ve released our new course with over 30 hours of video content.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: GPT 4 and the Uncharted Territories of Language
description: Language is a source of limitation and liberation. GPT 4 pushes this idea to the extreme by giving us access to unlimited language.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: I was an AI researcher. Now, I am an immunology student.
description: Last year, I became captivated by a new topic in a way that I hadn’t felt since I first discovered machine learning
author: Rachel Thomas

title: 1st Two Lessons of From Deep Learning Foundations to Stable Diffusion
description: 4 videos from Practical Deep Learning for Coders Part 2, 2022 have been released as a special early preview of the new course.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Deep Learning Foundations Signup, Open Source Scholarships, & More
description: Signups are now open for Practical Deep Learning for Coders Part 2, 2022. Scholarships are available for fast.ai community contributors, open source developers, and diversity scholars.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: From Deep Learning Foundations to Stable Diffusion
description: Practical Deep Learning for Coders part 2, 2022
author: Jeremy Howard

title: My family’s unlikely homeschooling journey
description: Prior to 2020, we never expected to homeschool, and now we have committed to it long-term.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: The Jupyter+git problem is now solved
description: Previously, using git with Jupyter could create conflicts and break notebooks. With nbdev2, the problem has been totally solved.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: nbdev+Quarto: A new secret weapon for productivity
description: Our favorite tool for software engineering productivity–nbdev, now re-written with Quarto
author: Hamel Husain and Jeremy Howard

title: Practical Deep Learning for Coders 2022
description: A complete from-scratch rewrite of fast.ai’s most popular course, that’s been 2 years in the making.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Masks for COVID: Updating the evidence
description: Notes taken whilst preparing a paper on mask efficacy from Nov to Jan 2022. My previous paper on this was written in April 2020 and published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Science
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Qualitative humanities research is crucial to AI
description: Following the thread of any seemingly quantitative issue in AI ethics (such as determining if software to rate loan applicants is racially biased or evaluating YouTube’s recommendation system) quickly leads to a host of qualitative questions. Unfortunately, there is often a large divide between computer scientists and social scientists, with over-simplified assumptions and fundamental misunderstandings of one another.
author: Louisa Bartolo and Rachel Thomas

title: AI Harms are Societal, Not Just Individual
description: In the west, our ideas of harm are largely anchored to an individual being harmed by a particular action at a discrete moment in time. Yet the harms caused by algorithmic systems are often collective and communal.
author: Rachel Thomas and Louisa Bartolo

title: There’s no such thing as not a math person
description: Many cultural factors, misconceptions, stereotypes, and obstacles turn people off to math.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: 7 Great Lightning Talks Related to Data Science Ethics
description: Lightning talks by Australian experts on a range of topics related to data science ethics, including machine learning in medicine, explainability, Indigenous-led AI, and the role of policy
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Doing Data Science for Social Good, Responsibly
description: While data for social good projects can be useful, there are also pitfalls to avoid.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Avoiding Data Disasters
description: Things can go disastrously wrong on data science and machine learning projects when we undervalue data work, use data in contexts that it wasn’t gathered for, or ignore the crucial role that humans play in the data science pipeline.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: SARS-CoV-2 Spike Protein Impairment of Endothelial Function Does Not Impact Vaccine Safety
description: All approved SARS-CoV-2 vaccines provide far more benefits than risks. The very rare risk of VITT from the AZ and JJ vaccines is not due to the spike proteins, but is most likely due to details of their formulation.
author: Jeremy Howard and Uri Manor

title: Statistical problems found when studying Long Covid in kids
description: Statistical tests need to be paired with proper data and study design to yield valid results. A recent review paper on Long Covid in children provides a useful example of how researchers can get this wrong. We use causal diagrams to decompose the problem and illustrate where errors were made.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Medicine is Political
description: From covid-19 to HIV research to the long history of wrongly assuming women’s illnesses are psychosomatic, we have seen again and again that medicine, like all science, is political.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Inaccuracies, irresponsible coverage, and conflicts of interest in The New Yorker
description: Letter to the editor of the New Yorker on the irresponsible description of a suicide, undisclosed financial conflicts of interest, and omission of relevant medical research and historical context in their recent long covid article
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Australia can, and must, get R under 1.0
description: By using better masks, monitoring and improving indoor air quality, and rolling out rapid tests, we could quickly halt the current outbreaks in the Australian states of New South Wales (NSW) and Victoria. If we fail to do so, and open up before 80% of all Australians are vaccinated, we may have tens of thousands of deaths, and hundreds of thousands of children with chronic illness which could last for years.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Getting Specific about AI Risks (an AI Taxonomy)
author: Rachel Thomas

title: 11 Short Videos About AI Ethics
author: Rachel Thomas

title: fastai A Layered API for Deep Learning
author: Jeremy Howard and Sylvain Gugger

title: fastdownload: the magic behind one of the famous 4 lines of code
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Is GitHub Copilot a blessing, or a curse?
author: Jeremy Howard

title: fastchan, a new conda mini-distribution
author: Jeremy Howard

title: 20 Years of Tech Startup Experiences in One Hour
author: Jeremy Howard

title: I violated a code of conduct
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Avoiding the smoke - how to breath clean air
description: You can use filters in your mask, your home central air, and your fans to clean the air in your home.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: fast.ai releases new deep learning course, four libraries, and 600-page book
description: We’re releasing Practical Deep Learning for Coders (2020), fastai v2, fastcore, and fastgpu.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Forward from the ‘Deep Learning for Coders’ Book
description: To celebrate the release of fast.ai’s new course, book, and software libraries on August 21st, we’re making available the foreword that Soumith Chintala (the co-creator of PyTorch) wrote for the book
author: Soumith Chintala

title: Applied Data Ethics, a new free course, is essential for all working in tech
description: Free, online course from fast.ai and University of San Francisco Data Institute covering disinformation, bias & fairness, ethical foundations, practical tools, privacy & surveillance, the silicon valley ecosystem, and algorithmic colonialism.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Essential Work-From-Home Advice: Cheap and Easy Ergonomic Setups
description: You can permanently damage your back, neck, and wrists from working without an ergonomic setup. Learn how to create one for less at home.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Cloth masks can protect the wearer
description: DIY masks aren’t just for protecting those around you. They can protect you too, but material and fit matters a lot. Learn what works, based on the latest research.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Particle sizes for mask filtration
description: SARS-CoV-2 does not float in the air. It’s expelled as large droplets, which are easily caught by a cloth mask.
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Introducing the first cohort of USF CADE Data Ethics Research Fellows
description: The University of San Francisco Center for Applied Data Ethics welcomes its first cohort of research fellows.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Masks - FAQ for Skeptics
description: Wearing a mask decreases the number of people infected by an infectious wearer, because it reduces by around 99% the number of droplets that are ejected during speech
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Masks for all? The science says yes.
description: Most scientific evidence points in the same direction: keep your droplets to yourself - wear a mask
author: Professor Trisha Greenhalgh OBE and Jeremy Howard

title: 6 Important Videos about Tech, Ethics, Policy, and Government
description: At the CADE Tech Policy Workshop, members of local government, activists, researchers, and those in industry shared prespectives on how to understand the uses, risks, and opporutnities around government use of technology.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Saving The Mask
description: An initiative from STEM teachers in Hong Kong to make reusable masks, for the community, by the community
author: Sarada Lee

title: Covid-19, your community, and you - a data science perspective
author: Jeremy Howard and Rachel Thomas

title: Disinformation: what it is, why it’s pervasive, and proposed regulations
description: At the CADE Tech Policy Workshop, experts Renee DiResta and Guillaume Chaslot spoke on disinformation, including the dyanmics that cause it to go viral and attempts towards addressing it.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Tech Ethics Crisis: The Big Picture, and How We Got Here
description: At the CADE Tech Policy Workshop, Y-Vonne Hutchinson spoke about the role of tech in facilitating mass atrocity, and Catherine Bracy spoke on the need for empathy and collective action.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: 4 Principles for Responsible Government Use of Technology
description: As governments consider new uses of technology, in public places, this raises issues around surveillance of vulnerable populations, unintended consequences, and potential misuse. There are several principles to keep in mind in how these decisions can be made in a healthier and more responsible manner.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Your own blog with GitHub Pages and fast_template (4 part tutorial)
description: Overview of 4 part series explaining how to host your own blog without any coding
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Blogging with Jupyter Notebooks
description: With Jupyter Notebooks and fast_template, we can easily share prose, code, tables, charts, and more!
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Blogging with screenshots
description: We show how to use fast_template’s special ‘screenshot’ feature to get high-resolution screenshots
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Syncing your blog with your PC, and using your word processor
description: With GitHub Pages you can synchronize your blog with your computer, and write posts with MS Word or Google Docs
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Your own hosted blog, the easy, free, open way (even if you’re not a computer expert)
description: An easy and free approach to using an entirely browser-based interface for all your blogging needs
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Self-supervised learning and computer vision
description: Pretrain a model using labels that are naturally part of the input data, instead of using external labels
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Data project checklist
description: There’s a lot more to creating useful data projects than just training an accurate model
author: Jeremy Howard

title: nbdev: use Jupyter Notebooks for everything
description: nbdev is a Python programming environment which allows you to create complete python packages, including tests and a rich documentation system, all in Jupyter Notebooks
author: Jeremy Howard

title: Concerned about the impacts of data misuse? Ways to get involved with the USF Center for Applied Data Ethics
description: Three months after the launch of CADE, find out what we’ve been up to and how you can get involved.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: The problem with metrics is a big problem for AI
description: Unthinkingly optimizing metrics can lead to a variety of grave harms, and what most current AI approaches do is to optimize metrics.
author: Rachel Thomas

title: 8 Things You Need to Know about Surveillance
author: Rachel Thomas

title: Make Delegation Work in Python
description: Fixing the delegation program using delegates decorator and GetAttr

title: USF Launches New Center of Applied Data Ethics

title: new fast.ai course: A Code-First Introduction to Natural Language Processing
description: fast.ai’s newest course is Code-First Intro to NLP. It covers a blend of traditional NLP techniques, recent deep learning approaches, and urgent ethical issues.
